lg.l: The worship and great things done here won't reach
those in heaven, if heaven dry up.

div.p: (i-ḷ). tēvarkaṭku mivvulakiṉkaṇ makkaḷāṟ ceyyappaṭum viḻavoṭukūṭiya pūcai naṭavātu, maḻai peyyātāyiṉ, (e-ṟu).
The meaning ... : For the gods, also, the worship done by people in this world, which comes along with festivals, would not happen(/come), if rain did not pour.
naimittikattōṭu kūṭiya nittiya meṉṟārākaliṉ ‘cellātu’ eṉṟār. ummai ciṟappummai. nittiyattiṟ ṟāḻvu tīracceyvatu naimittika mātaliṉ ataṉai muṟkūṟiṉār.

Because he has said that daily worship is accompanied by [festivals, i.e.] occasional worship, [the poet] has said "does not go"(???). The particle -um ("even") shows high degree. [I.e., "even" the gods will suffer from want of rain on Earth]. Because the occasional worship puts an end to the exhaustion(?) [produced by] daily worship, [the poet] has mentioned it first.
(i - ḷ.) ciṟappuc ceyyappaṭukiṉṟa viḻavu pūcaṉai naṭavātu; vāṉam pularumākil tēvarkaḷukkum ivvulakiṉkaṇ, (e - ṟu).
The meaning ... : Festive worship that is made excellent, if rain dried up, would also not make its way to the gods, in this world.
maḻaipeyyākkāl varuṅ kuṟṟaṅ kūṟuvār muṟpaṭa nāṉkuvakaippaṭṭa aṟaṅkaḷil pūcai keṭumeṉṟār.

Being about to describe [in this section](?) the distress that comes about when rain does not pour, [the poet] has said that, among the four kinds of dharma [mentioned] in the previous [section?], worship would disappear.
